Quad Quips
By JACK STEIN
I happened to be looking over the NEWS-LETTER finances the other day, and came upon the startling discovery that it costs over $65 to print one issue of the
NEWS-LETTER. That figure set me to work. Invoking
calculus, algebra, solid and plane geometry, trig, and
other sundry forms of the mathematical science, I was
able to learn that it costs over $4.00 every time this
column is printed. Four crisp bills, plus change, is represented in these weighty words of wisdom.
Doing a little more figuring I find that every time
the paper uses the picture of a professor it costs over
$.50. (When pictures of students are used it may cost
more than ordinary, because they require more space
in view of their swell heads.) An ordinary headline on
the front page alone runs into more than $.60.
I think it about time the student body awakened
to the fact that the NEWS-LETTER represents a good
deal of cold cash, and instead of tossing your NEWSLETTER in the waste basket, why not refund it at the
NEWS-LETTER office? Yeah! Why not?
At present the paper is running a terrific deficit,
and the Editor asks that all students who would like
to see the paper become financially "on its feet," please
give slugs, lead nickels, Defend Ethiopia buttons, collar
buttons, etc., all of which will be melted into a heap—
the silver extracted—and a bright shiny two-bit piece
made which will be used to reduce the deficit. Thank
you.

Just one. Granting the above, the R. 0. T. C. is
purely a weapon of indoctrination. Though not preparing men for war, it prepares them for the idea of war—
it prepares them to accept the bearing of arms against
total strangers as not an irrational practice. It is an
expensive piece of propaganda.

The second point:
4 (a)—That we refuse to support the government
of the United States in any war in which it may engage.
(b)—That we refuse to support the government of
the United States in any aggressive war it may undertake.
We refuse to support the government of the United
States in any aggressive war it may undertake.
Furthermore, with the treacherous development of
modern diplomacy—hypocrisy, no distinction can be
made between an offensive and a defensive war between powers of equal strength.
We will not fight for somebody else.
We will fight to preserve principles we have or
think we have. If some nation were to invade our country and attempt to impose upon us certain doctrines
or practices that we hold irrevocably untenable, we
would risk our lives against an unlivable condition.
If Germany were to land troops on our shores, we
believe that those of us who feel that there would be
no living under the Nazi system of restrictions should
gamble our lives. There are those who look upon Fascism (including Naziism) as but a form of capitalism,
and who feel that there is not enough difference between any two forms of capitalism to excuse a drop
of spilled blood.
We cannot deny the legitimacy of that view.

On how and what to do,
Out dropped a girl who was very shy
And thus there were only two.
The course continued right along
Studying the forms of life,
A Bio boy loved a Bio girl,
And soon became man and wife..

Well, to start with, we take tobacco

A team consisting mostly of second-stringers began the second half
for Hopkins against an opposition of
reserves. With the removal of its
first team backfield, which included
its two stars—Apichella and Kuratnick, Mt. St. Mary's power was very
much reduced. Nevertheless, the Emmitsburg boys managed to score
twice more before the end of the
game.
However,
the
Hopkins'
ends and tackles played brilliantly
on the defense, forcing the Saints to
direct their attack to the center of
the line. Tommy Ellis, left tackle,
plugged up the holes on the left end.
while speedy Zeeny Baum kept the
Saints' attack from
functioning
around the right. Vincenti proved
himself the surest tackler in the
secondary.
The opening home game was not
taken too much to heart by the
Hopkins squad. The team is now
looking forward to its game with St.
John's a week from next Saturday.

are raving mad and rarin' to go!

Quad Quips
By JACK STEIN
I happened to be looking over the NEWS-LETTER finances the other day, and came upon the startling discovery that it costs over $65 to print one issue of the
NEWS-LETTER. That figure set me to work. Invoking
calculus, algebra, solid and plane geometry, trig, and
other sundry forms of the mathematical science, I was
able to learn that it costs over $4.00 every time this
column is printed. Four crisp bills, plus change, is represented in these weighty words of wisdom.
Doing a little more figuring I find that every time
the paper uses the picture of a professor it costs over
$.50. (When pictures of students are used it may cost
more than ordinary, because they require more space
in view of their swell heads.) An ordinary headline on
the front page alone runs into more than $.60.
I think it about time the student body awakened
to the fact that the NEWS-LETTER represents a good
deal of cold cash, and instead of tossing your NEWSLETTER in the waste basket, why not refund it at the
NEWS-LETTER office? Yeah! Why not?
At present the paper is running a terrific deficit,
and the Editor asks that all students who would like
to see the paper become financially "on its feet," please
give slugs, lead nickels, Defend Ethiopia buttons, collar
buttons, etc., all of which will be melted into a heap—
the silver extracted—and a bright shiny two-bit piece
made which will be used to reduce the deficit. Thank
you.

purely a weapon of indoctrination. Though not preparing men for war, it prepares them for the idea of war—
it prepares them to accept the bearing of arms against
total strangers as not an irrational practice. It is an
expensive piece of propaganda.

4 (a)—That we refuse to support the government
of the United States in any war in which it may engage.
(b)—That we refuse to support the government of
the United States in any aggressive war it may undertake.
We refuse to support the government of the United
States in any aggressive war it may undertake.
Furthermore, with the treacherous development of
modern diplomacy—hypocrisy, no distinction can be
made between an offensive and a defensive war between powers of equal strength.
We will not fight for somebody else.
We will fight to preserve principles we have or
think we have. If some nation were to invade our country and attempt to impose upon us certain doctrines
or practices that we hold irrevocably untenable, we
would risk our lives against an unlivable condition.
If Germany were to land troops on our shores, we
believe that those of us who feel that there would be
no living under the Nazi system of restrictions should
gamble our lives. There are those who look upon Fascism (including Naziism) as but a form of capitalism,
and who feel that there is not enough difference between any two forms of capitalism to excuse a drop
of spilled blood.
We cannot deny the legitimacy of that view.

Studying the forms of life,
A Bio boy loved a Bio girl,
And soon became man and wife..

Score Rolls Up
The second period AV, the powerhouse from the Mount really put on
the pressure. It ripped its opponent's
forward wall wide open time and
time again. Its single, double, and
triple reverses, executed by a set of
fast, hard-plunging, shifty backs,
behind a line which outweighed Hopkins by 20 pounds to the man, were
too much for the Jay defense. When
the half was over, four more touchdowns had been added to the Mt. St.
Mary's score. Ward, the Jays' fullback, and left tackle Pinsky, by their
sparkling defensive play, made the
burden a little easier -for Coach
George Darley.

for Hopkins against an opposition of
reserves. With the removal of its
first team backfield, which included

game.
However,
the
Hopkins'
ends and tackles played brilliantly
